title: ISO 29148 Supplier Alignment Sprint
theme: Unify requirements for a multinational avionics supplier network
overview:
Three aerospace contracts are being consolidated into a single supplier agreement. Each vendor keeps its own tooling, but the airworthiness authority expects a unified requirement set that satisfies ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148 guidance on stakeholder needs, specification content, and acceptance evidence.

This sprint pushes students to translate procurement statements into well-formed requirements, maintain traceability across suppliers, and demonstrate validation readiness before the joint design review.

labs.title: Acquisition Discovery Sprint
labs.summary: Clarify stakeholder intent, contractual boundaries, and operational context (clauses 5-6).

labs.title: Specification Governance Workshop
labs.summary: Structure requirement statements, assign identifiers, and prepare traceability controls (clauses 7-9).

labs.title: Contract Validation Loop
labs.summary: Plan verification and validation evidence the contracting officer will expect (clauses 10-11).

resources: Annex F – Checklist for requirement statements
NATO AQAP references for supplier traceability
UFV instructor memo: always cite contractual source for every constraint
completionMessage: Present the consolidated requirement pack to the contracting officer and record pending supplier clarifications.

challenges.title: Supplier Landscape Brief
challenges.narrative: Each avionics supplier brings a different certification history. ISO 29148 clause 6.4 forces the team to capture context and stakeholder goals before locking anything into the specification.
objectives: Map environment, user, and equipment factors for each supplier
Identify contractual drivers behind stakeholder needs
Document conflicts that will require negotiation

tasks.content: Read the supplier onboarding transcript. Highlight statements about tooling, regulatory ownership, and turnaround expectations.
tasks.helper: Use one column per supplier so overlaps stand out.

tasks.instruction: Complete the acquisition context brief with persona, certification, delegated authority, and unacceptable loss for at least three roles (contracting officer, prime integrator, avionics QA).
tasks.example: Prime integrator – needs supplier data in ASD S1000D structure within 24 hours of change.

tasks.instruction: Interview the instructor acting as Export Control Counsel to uncover hidden constraints (e.g., data residency, handling levels).
tasks.helper: Write exact regulation names so every derived requirement can cite them.

tasks.instruction: Produce a Supplier Landscape Brief summarizing context-of-use, top risks, and the clauses you will reference in negotiations.
tasks.helper: Tie each risk to the ISO 29148 activity it influences (elicitation, analysis, specification).

quizzes.question: Why does ISO 29148 demand recording the source stakeholder for every need?
choices: To maintain traceability between stakeholder intent and resulting requirements
quizzes.rationale: Without a documented source you cannot prove the requirement is necessary when auditors ask.

quizzes.question: Which artifact best captures user, environment, and equipment information before specification drafting?
quizzes.rationale: Clause 6.4 highlights the context-of-use description as the anchor for downstream requirements.

challenges.nextStepCue: Share the brief with your table and agree on which conflicts must be escalated before the next lab.

challenges.title: Requirement Vetting Board
challenges.narrative: Statements arrive from supplier kickoff workshops. Annex F and Annex D of ISO 29148 define the qualities the board must check before accepting them into the contract baseline.

tasks.content: Sort the supplier comments into Need, Constraint, Design Suggestion. Highlight any statement missing a measurable trigger.
tasks.helper: If a note mentions 'friendly interface', capture the underlying quality metric you need.

tasks.instruction: Rewrite five needs into ISO 29148 requirement format (context, subject, modal verb, measurable outcome).
tasks.helper: Include the supplier ID (SUP-A, SUP-B, etc.) so traceability remains obvious.

tasks.instruction: Score each rewritten requirement against the Necessary/Unambiguous/Feasible/Verifiable criteria.
Publish the vetted requirement list with scores, open issues, and the supplier contact able to clarify each.
tasks.helper: Flag TBD attributes so the contracting officer can chase answers.

quizzes.question: An acceptable ISO 29148 requirement must be…
quizzes.rationale: Annex D lists these attributes as mandatory quality characteristics.

quizzes.question: What is the best next step when a statement mixes two actions?
choices: Split it into separate requirements so each is singular
Turn it into a test case
quizzes.rationale: Singular requirements improve clarity and allow precise verification.

challenges.nextStepCue: Move the approved statements into the specification outline to keep momentum.

challenges.title: Specification Outline Alignment
challenges.narrative: The acquisition office wants to see how requirements map to ISO 29148 clause 9 sections and supplier responsibilities.
objectives: Assign each requirement to a specification section
Reference contractual clauses for derived requirements
Draft narrative bridges explaining why sections exist

tasks.content: Review the specification skeleton (scope, referenced documents, functional, performance, interface, verification).
tasks.helper: Note which sections each supplier already maintains.

tasks.instruction: Create a story map linking each validated requirement to specification sections and supplier IDs.
tasks.helper: Use SUP-<section>-<number> so auditors know where the requirement lives.

tasks.instruction: Ask the instructor role-playing the Certification Auditor which references must appear verbatim (e.g., SAE ARP4754A, RTCA DO-178C).
tasks.helper: Capture clause numbers for later traceability.

tasks.instruction: Draft introductory paragraphs for two critical sections, citing ISO 29148 clause numbers and supplier responsibilities.
tasks.helper: Close each paragraph with a measurable commitment rather than design statements.

quizzes.question: Where should interface requirements sit per ISO 29148?
choices: Within a dedicated interface section so downstream teams can plan integrations
quizzes.rationale: Clause 9 describes interface requirements as their own content element.

quizzes.question: Derived requirements created from regulatory constraints must…
choices: Cite the originating regulation for traceability
quizzes.rationale: ISO 29148 expects each requirement to point back to its source (stakeholder, regulation, standard).

challenges.nextStepCue: Review the outline with the contracting officer before numbering requirements.

challenges.title: Traceability & Change Drill
challenges.narrative: Supplier changes are inevitable. Clause 7.2.5 mandates bidirectional traceability and impact analysis before approving modifications.
objectives: Assess change impact on suppliers and interfaces

tasks.instruction: Fill the traceability matrix with stakeholder IDs, supplier IDs, requirement IDs, and planned verification methods.
tasks.helper: Adopt the ID convention SUP-REQ-### for requirements and SUP-VER-### for verification steps.

tasks.instruction: Choose one requirement and draft three verification approaches (analysis, test, inspection) with pass/fail criteria.
tasks.example: Inspection – verify supplier delivers DO-178C artifacts before flight clearance.

tasks.instruction: Simulate a change request: 'Supplier B wants to defer fail-operational capability to phase 2.' Document interface, validation, and contractual impacts.
tasks.helper: Indicate whether the change touches safety assessments or airworthiness evidence.

tasks.instruction: Brief the instructor on the traceability snapshot and change analysis, highlighting which artifacts must be re-baselined.
tasks.helper: Mention who owns the decision (contracting officer vs. supplier PM).

quizzes.question: Bidirectional traceability means…
choices: Requirements connect to both their sources and their verification evidence
Stakeholders no longer need to sign off
quizzes.rationale: Clause 7.2.5 stresses linking requirements back to their origins and forward to verification artifacts.

quizzes.question: When processing a change request you should first…
choices: Check which requirement IDs are affected and what verification updates they need
quizzes.rationale: Impact analysis starts by identifying the affected requirements and their dependent artifacts.

challenges.nextStepCue: Lock IDs before presenting validation coverage.

challenges.title: Joint Validation Pack
challenges.narrative: Auditors expect a clear validation plan mapping requirements to acceptance criteria, owners, and evidence.
objectives: Plan validation activities per requirement category
Craft the executive summary for the design review

tasks.content: Review the verification approaches captured earlier and decide which require customer witnessing.
tasks.helper: Disclose where supplier labs can provide evidence vs. where the customer must participate.

tasks.instruction: Draft acceptance criteria (metric, benchmark, evidence owner, validation method) for three priority requirements.
Write validation protocol notes describing how the contracting officer will accept or reject evidence.
tasks.helper: Reference ISO 29148 clause 10 to justify each activity.

tasks.instruction: Compose the executive message summarizing readiness, residual risks, and the next design review milestone.
tasks.helper: Mention which supplier owes additional data so accountability stays visible.

quizzes.question: A valid acceptance criterion must…
choices: Contain a measurable threshold tied to a requirement
quizzes.rationale: ISO 29148 emphasizes measurability to confirm requirement satisfaction.

quizzes.question: Validation focuses on…
quizzes.rationale: Validation ensures the delivered capability satisfies stakeholder intent, not just technical specs.

challenges.nextStepCue: Send the validation pack to the contracting officer for review and capture any feedback in the traceability log.
